data.text: Contents
Infection prevention and control principles of ANTT ..................................................... 9
Introduction

An  aseptic  technique  aims  to  prevent  micro-organisms  on  hands,  from  the inanimate environment or equipment, being introduced into a susceptible site on the patient during clinical procedures. Aseptic technique should also prevent micro- organisms from the patient being transferred to staff and other patients (Wilson 2006).

Aseptic Non Touch Technique (ANTT) is a framework for ensuring the consistent application of the principles of asepsis across a range of clinical procedures. It focuses on the identification of key parts and susceptible sites and protecting them from contamination during the procedure (Rowley & Clare 2009). ANTT aims to improve  practice  by  instituting  a  standardised  approach  to  performing  aseptic technique in all clinical settings from surgery to community care.
Scope

This policy applies to all staff who undertake clinical procedures on the use of ANTT. This is the responsibility of every member of staff who is involved in clinical practice to ensure that they are trained in ANTT and maintain their competency.
Definitions

table_items.text: is the method used to prevent microbial contamination during an invasive procedure, or care of breeches in the skin (ICNA 2003)
is a practice or procedure undertaken for a patient and is designed to ensure the freedom from microbial contamination
A general term that applies to hand washing, antiseptic hand wash, antiseptic hand rub, or surgical hand antisepsis.
A medical procedure that invades (enters) the body, usually by cutting or puncturing the skin or by inserting instruments into the body cavity
Any part of a piece of equipment used during aseptic technique that will increase the risk of infection if contaminated by infectious material
A method of changing a dressing without directly touching the wound or any other surface which might come into contact with the wound.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust

Infection Prevention and Control Site Committees (IPCC's) are responsible for the review of this policy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation or guidance

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors
The  Director  for  Infection  Prevention  and  Control  (DIPC)   has  operational responsibly for the effective implementation of this policy
The Head of Infection Control MSE will act on legislation, national policies and guidance ensuring effective policies are in place and audited in relation to standard precautions

The Infection Prevention and Control Sites Teams are responsible for ensuring all staff are made aware of this policy and provide expert professional advice and education on the prevention and control of infection including standard precautions, to other professionals, multi-disciplinary groups, patients and carers

All Staff must comply with this policy and act in a responsible manner, liaising with the IPCT in a timely manner if in need of advice or support. All staff have a responsibility to ensure that infection prevention is embedded into their everyday practice and applied consistently at all times
Procedure for full aseptic technique

table_items.text: Staff must adopt the ‘bare below the elbows' principle, as per trust uniform policy. Sleeves must be short or rolled up, and hand or wrist jewellery must not be worn. Ties and necklaces must be removed. Long hair must be tied back
These may dangle into the sterile field.
Prepare the patient, including explaining the procedure to be undertaken; remove any soiled wound dressings wearing non- sterile gloves
To gain patient consent and co operation To prevent cross infection
Prior to undertaking the intervention staff MUST: Ensure windows are closed Ensure fans are turned off Draw curtains around the bed Limit the number of people who will be entering the area
Environmental risks are removed or avoided and patient dignity is maintained
Prepare the setting – decontaminate the working surface trolley (if available) with Clinell universal wipes
To provide a clean working surface

The use of drapes and protective clothing will depend on the type of procedure and its complexity. Large drapes and maximum barrier precautions are required for surgical procedures and central venous catheter insertion. Sterile gloves, a clean disposable apron and a small drape are all required for wound dressings and urethral catheter insertion
To protect key parts and key sites
Wash hands with liquid soap and dry with paper towels.
To reduce the risk of spreading infection.
When opening packaged sterile items, do so carefully by peeling back the packaging and avoid touching the contents
Decontaminate hands and don appropriate protective clothing
Create a sterile field with the use of the appropriate drapes
Perform the procedure, avoiding accidental contamination of the sterile equipment or vulnerable site
Change gloves and decontaminate hands again if at any stage contamination occurs
On completion of procedure decontaminate hands

data.text: Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT)

table_items.text: Staff must adopt the ‘bare below the elbows' principle, as per trust uniform policy. Sleeves must be short or rolled up, and hand or wrist jewellery must not be worn. Ties and necklaces must be removed Long hair must be tied back
These may dangle into the sterile field and contaminate it.

Prepare the patient, including explaining the procedure to be undertaken; When changing a wound dressing remove any soiled wound dressings wearing non- sterile gloves and place into the clinical waste bag, change gloves and decontaminate hands
To ensure that the patient understands the procedure and gives his or her valid consent.To prevent cross infection
Effective hand decontamination is essential to ANTT and should take place prior to and after
Clean hands before and after every patient contact and before
all invasive techniques and after the removal of gloves.

Prior to undertaking the intervention staff MUST: Ensure the environment is clean and tidy Ensure windows are closed Ensure fans are turned off Draw curtains around the bed Limit the number of people who will be entering the area
Environmental risks are removed or avoided and patient dignity is maintained

Prepare the basic aseptic field such as a well cleaned tray or trolley Equipment used during ANTT such as plastic trays or dressing trolleys must be thoroughly cleaned before and after use. If the equipment is visibly soiled or not in regular use, clean with soap and water and dry thoroughly Immediately prior to use, clean the equipment with Clinell Universal Wipes and allow to air dry After use, clean the equipment from the inside to outside with a Clinell Universal Wipe or soap and water and dry thoroughly
To provide a clean working surface. If not dry it is not aseptic
When cleaning a wound clean from the cleanest to the most soiled area
A non-touch technique will help protect the wound from colonisation or infection.

A non-touch technique will help protect the wound from colonisation or infection. Dispose of equipment, waste and gloves folding the used equipment and waste into the aseptic field drape and disposing it in the attached waste bag will minimise the movement of waste and protect the wider working environment.
Keep field clean and tidy throughout the procedure, only necessary equipment that is needed for the procedure should enter the aseptic field
To ensure an aseptic technique is delivered

Use clean non-sterile gloves Sterile gloves, a clean disposable apron and a small drape are all required for wound dressings, urethral catheter insertion and when accessing a central venous access device or ‘Midline'

Sterile gloves are not required as the non-touch aseptic technique maintains asepsis other than in the aforementioned procedures or when repeatedly accession a central venous device in critical care or emergency area

Do not touch “key parts” of the equipment or key sites on the patient during the procedure. Key parts are those parts of equipment that if contaminated by infectious material increase the risk of infection. Key sites are wounds or insertion sites of medical devices. This means avoiding touching: In IV therapy: needle and needle hub syringe tips exposed peripheral/central line lumens both ends of infusion sets hubs of intravenous medication vials In wound care: all parts of dressing pack wound Ensure equipment is not dropped onto the aseptic field

A core component of ANTT is maintaining asepsis during invasive procedures. Key parts are those parts of equipment that is contaminated by infectious material increase the risk of infection, not touching them either directly or indirectly is perhaps the single most important component of achieving asepsis To maintain a sterile field
On completion of procedure decontaminate hands wash tray or trolley with hot soapy water and leave to air dry
When accessing a needle free connector Clean the site for 30 seconds with 2% chlorhexidine and 70% alcohol impregnated wipe and allow time to dry
Need free connectors must be placed on all vascular access device lumen

data.text: Infection prevention and control principles of ANTT
Always decontaminate hands effectively
Never contaminate ‘key parts' of the equipment or the patients' susceptible site Touch non ‘key parts' of the equipment with confidence
Take appropriate infection prevention and control precautions

Non-sterile gloves should be worn in most cases as sterile gloves are only necessary if the procedure requires a ‘surgical' approach or the operator cannot carry out the procedure without the risk of touching a key part. E.g. wound dressings, urethral catheter insertion and when accessing a central venous access device or ‘Midline'
The ANTT environment is also critical and cleanliness of the tray must be achieved
Training requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control updates. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs and ensuring staff have the  necessary  competency  in  accessing  central  venous  access  devices  with appropriate infection control.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Site Infection Prevention and Control Committees which are the specialist groups with the authority to approve local policy. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
